Those of us with ADHD struggle to remember things every day. It's something we have learned to live with our entire lives, and a lot of times the people around us just don't understand. So, why do people with ADHD struggle to remember things?

description:

We've talked a little bit about Relationship accommodations on the channel before, but today lets deep dive into what works and doesn't work in my own relationship with my AuDHD partner! (Autistic + ADHD)

09:58 CoPilot
11:33 What We Do Differently Now...
12:47 Demanding From The Wrong Restaurant
13:45 Learning New Expectations
14:24 How Our Expectations Are Accommodated
17:28 Comment Below if Dr. B Is Not A Jerk!
18:05 Expressing Limits
18:29 Adjusting What You're Asking For
19:40 Wrap-up
20:18 Thank You To Our Brain Advocates!
20:34 Takethis.org
21:04 Outro

description:
Get 40% off Blinkist premium, only valid until February! Enjoy 2 memberships for the price of 1. Start your 7-day free trial by clicking here: https://www.blinkist.com/howtoadhd

We've all probably heard of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, or CBT, before (and if you haven't then this video is still great for you). The question is, what exactly is it, and why can CBT be helpful for those of us with ADHD?

title: Why ADHDers Can't ALWAYS Procrastinate #shorts #adhd
description:
Here are some of our videos relating to how to study that also explains some of the process of memory encoding!

https://youtu.be/qE9Pmm5yfhQ
https://youtu.be/PZ4wWpPf-go
https://youtu.be/MVBFCayoEF4

-- Transcription --

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with occasional displayed text matching what Jess says. Most visual elements are not described at this time.]

[video begins]

Jess speaking:
Do you procrastinate? Of course you do.

We all procrastinate sometimes. And those with ADHD can sometimes procrastinate a little more often, and, that can be fine, as long as it's mindful. 

If you're going to procrastinate, procrastinate mindfully.

But there are some things you cannot procrastinate on and still have it turn out well. 

One of those is studying. Our brains need time to consolidate the information that we've learned into long-term storage.

And they need practice recalling that information from long-term storage and then putting it back into long-term storage.

So, it takes time, it takes several nights. It's a lot more effective to study for 10 minutes a night before you go to bed, for a week, than it is to study for 3 hours the night before a test.

Also, if you happen to be staying up late to study, skipping sleep can affect memory recall.

So, at that point, if you haven't studied yet, you might as well sleep.

[end of video]

title: One Way to Stay Focused When You Have ADHD #adhd #shorts
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thank you Hyrulistic!)

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with occasional displayed text matching what Jess says. Most visual elements are not described at this time.]

[video begins]

Jess speaking:

This isn't a notebook. It's my parking lot! 
[video plays a sound effect of a car horn beeping] 

One of the reasons it's really hard for ADHD-ers to stay focused is, our brain keeps reminding us of other things that we need to do.

And sometimes, we go and do those things, because we don't want to forget, and also it's really hard to work when your brain keeps reminding you of something that you haven't done yet.

[Jess starts poking at the screen, like a nagging thought]
Did you do the thing? Did you do the thing? Don't forget to do the thing!

[Jess resumes speaking]
Enter: the parking lot!

When you're finished working on whatever you're working on, you can take a look, and see if any of it actually needs to get done right away.

[end of video]

title: Is ADHD a Behavioral Issue? #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thank you Hyrulistic!) 

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with displayed text only during the beginning, matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time.]

[video begins]

Jess speaking:
Something I get asked a lot:
Does punishment help with ADHD?

ADHD used to be considered a behavioural issue. And people thought these kids running around, misbehaving, not sitting still, getting distracted...needed more discipline, or that they didn't care.

Now, we know that's not true. It's not actually a behavioural issue, it's neurological. And the differences in behaviour are due to differences in the brain. 

And, no, punishment will not get rid of our ADHD. In fact, ADHD brains don't actually respond as well to punishment as neurotypical brains do.

It's not that we're misbehaving. We're struggling.

But, immediate positive feedback and salient rewards are actually more effective for ADHD brains than they are for neurotypical brains. 

ADHD isn't a behavioural issue. It's a neuro developmental disorder.

[end of video]
caption: false
localizations.en.title: Is ADHD a Behavioral Issue? #shorts #adhd

title: When People Say "ADHD isn't that Big a Deal" #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thank you Hyrulistic!) 

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with displayed text only during the beginning, matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time.]

[video begins]

Jess speaking:
It's really easy to dismiss ADHD as "Not that big a deal", because the things that people with ADHD struggle with, are things that everyone struggles with sometimes.

"Everyone gets distracted", "Everyone loses things", "Everyone forgets things".

While yes, these are things that everyone struggles with, not everyone struggles with it to the degree and the frequency that those with ADHD struggle with it

For us, it is a big deal.

While it might not be a big deal to occasionally lose something, when you lose something everyday, several times a day, it does become a big deal.

It starts to really interfere with your life.

[end of video]
caption: false

title: Grounding Techniques #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with displayed text only during the beginning, matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time.]

[video begins]

Jess speaking:
There is a widely used sensory grounding technique called the "5 4 3 2 1 Technique."

5. Notice 5 things you can see around you.
4. Notice 4 things you can touch or feel around you.
3. Notice 3 things you can hear.
2. Notice 2 things you can smell.
1. Notice 1 thing you can taste.


[end of video]
caption: false

title: What Can You Do About an Out of Control Inbox?? #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thank you Hyrulistic!)

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with displayed text only during the beginning, matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time.]

[video begins]

Jess speaking:
My email inbox is out of control!
Or is it?

So once or twice a day, I scan through my emails, looking for anything urgent that needs to be replied to. 

If it needs to be replied to and it's time sensitive, I reply to it right away.

If it's something I would like to reply to, if I have time, I star it. Later, if I have time in the day, I will go back and respond to those, and if I don't, it's OK, it's not time sensitive.

If I need to go back and find or reference an email, I use the search function. If I find that too many emails are coming in, and I'm missing things, or things are getting overwhelming, I start unsubscribing.

That's it! That is what I do.

Do I use tags, or folders, or any of that? I have tried, it has not worked for me, I do not do it.

If your email system is working for you, meaning you're not missing vital information and you can find the emails you need when you need to, that system works!

[end of video]
caption: false
localizations.en.title: What Can You Do About an Out of Control Inbox?? #shorts #adhd

title: How to be a Neurodiverse Ally! #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with occasional displayed text matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time.]

Jess speaking: 
This is my top 3 ways to be an ally to those who are neurodivergent.

1. Recognize that people are neurodiverse.
Just like there's diversity in gender, ethnicity, eye colour, and hair colour, there is diversity in the way brains work. So don't expect somebody else's brain to work the same way yours does, or for something that worked for you, to work for them.

What's cognitively easy for one person might actually be really cognitively challenging for another.

2. Listen to and believe your neurodivergent associates. 
When they tell you how their brain works, believe them! Just because you know about autism or ADHD or learning disabilities in general, doesn't mean you necessarily know how your individual coworker works. 
But that said, ask for consent, because not everybody is comfortable talking about this, and even those who are, don't necessarily feel comfortable talking about it right then.

And finally: 3. Include people who are neurodivergent in policies and programs that affect them.
There are a lot of programs and services that are meant to support people who are neurodivergent. Advocate for your neurodivergent peers, and make sure that they have a seat at the table when policies are discussed. 

Nothing about us, without us!

[end of video]
caption: false
localizations.en.title: How to be a Neurodiverse Ally! #shorts #adhd

title: How to ACTUALLY be ontime when you have ADHD #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thank you Hyrulistic!)

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with occasional displayed text matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time]

Jess speaking:
Have you ever noticed it's really impossible to get somewhere right on time?
That's because right on time is like an exact minute, and that's a very small target to hit.

So I have a new strategy, which is to create windows of time for myself. If I need to be somewhere at 5, and I have to drive there, I'll aim for between 4:45 and 5:00.
If that's my window, then probably I'm going to be early. Not so early that my ADHD brain is going to be like, "Why?? This is so boring and long and forever taking!"
But, I can still play that game of: "Can I get there on time"; but my target is now 4:45.

I don't think any strategy in the world is going to make it so that we're never late. Everyone is late sometimes, but I hope this helps you a little bit. 


[end of video]
caption: false
localizations.en.title: How to ACTUALLY be ontime when you have ADHD #shorts #adhd

title: Most Doctors Don't Know a lot about ADHD #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thank you, Hyrulistic!)

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with occasional displayed text matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time]

Jess speaking:
Most doctors don't know a lot about ADHD.
In medical school, ADHD is still considered "not that big a deal", and often even those who are studying psychology don't learn a lot about it in school. 
So it's really important, if you can, to go to somebody who specializes in ADHD. 

And the reason for that is: any mental health professional is going to have to take continuing education credits, which means they're having to learn new things every year. 
And if ADHD is something they specialize in, that means that they are actually getting that education on ADHD that they need, to be able to treat it properly. 

So if you can, if you have the choice to, go with somebody who understands and specializes in ADHD. 
Because a lot of doctors, don't.


[end of video]
caption: false

title: ADHD In Disguise 🥸: How symptoms can sometimes look like depression #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thanks Hyrulistic!)

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with occasional displayed text matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time]

Jess speaking:
Some of the most common symptoms of ADHD are:
lack of motivation, difficulty with focusing and attention, insomnia, and sudden dark moods, or mood swings

These are all also common signs of depression.

While it's totally normal to relate to signs of a specific condition on TikTok, a lot of conditions share symptoms. So it's important to talk to a counsellor, or a psychologist, or your doctor, about any symptoms you might be having.

Sometimes ADHD and depression can look really similar. 
Especially from the outside.

In the US, Psychology Today's "Therapist Finder" is a really good place to start.

[end of video]
caption: false

title: One Way ADHDers Tend to Over Commit #shorts #adhd
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thank you, Hyrulistic!)

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with displayed text matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time]

Jess speaking:
Do you ever find yourself saying something like: I can't come this time, but next time I'll help you plan it!

These consolation commitments are a result of us feeling guilty when we can't say yes to someone when they ask for something.

Because we feel guilty, we often feel like we need to "make up for it", by not only doing what they wanted us to do this time, but doing more than that to make up for the fact that we didn't.

This can eat up a lot of our time and energy, which is a problem, because if we're already so busy that we can't do this thing now, the odds that we're going to have even more time and energy in the future are probably not great.

So, it can help to remember that your time and energy are yours. And you don't owe them to anyone else.
When someone asks you for a favour, you can say no.
And, "no," is a complete sentence.

[end of video]
caption: false
localizations.en.title: One Way ADHDers Tend to Over Commit #shorts #adhd

title: How to avoid making impulsive decisions in the moment 🤔 🤐 #shorts #adhd #impulse
description:
-- Transcription --
(Thank you Hyrulistic for the transcription help!)

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with displayed text only during the beginning, matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time]

Jess speaking:
We know ADHD-ers tend to struggle with Executive Function Challenges, but did you know that there are actually two Executive Function systems: 
Hot and Cold. 

When emotional stakes are high, our Hot Executive Function comes into play. 
Our Hot Executive Function tells us how we should feel based on the current situation and to behave accordingly. 
It's essentially our knee-jerk reaction.

Our Cool Executive Function, on the other hand, uses abstract logic and critical analysis.
That means when we're using our Cool Executive Function, we're making decisions based on data, information, or logic, rather than emotion.

Usually the best decisions are made when we take all of this information into account: Our emotions and the data and information. 

So a cool brain hack for making better decisions is to take note of how we're feeling in the moment, and then wait for our Cool Executive Function to kick in when we're calm, cool, and collected, so that we get the data and information we need to make a good decision overall.

[end of video]
caption: false
localizations.en.title: How to avoid making impulsive decisions in the moment 🤔 🤐 #shorts #adhd #impulse

title: What to do if you're having trouble focusing? #adhd #shorts #focus
description:
Disclaimer: This is just how Jessica uses the pomodoro technique! This does not mean it'll work for everyone or that the way you're doing it is wrong. 🧡

TRANSCRIPTION: 
(Thank you Hyrulistic!) 

[Note: this video is primarily spoken dialogue with displayed text only during the beginning, matching what Jess says. Visual elements are not described at this time.]

[video begins]

Jess: 
Are you having trouble focusing on something?
This is my secret weapon for focusing: a Pomodoro.

Here's how it works:
Choose a task to work on, set the timer for 25 minutes.
And for the duration of that timer, I'm not allowed to do anything else.
If I think of something else that I suddenly urgently do need to do, I write it down.
 
And then I guard my pomodoro with my life.
I do not do anything else while that timer is running.
I only use them occasionally because focusing is hard, and so eventually, if I'm using them a lot, I'm probably not going to respect the Pomodoro and I'll start doing other things while the timer is still going. 
I don't want to do that. This is my absolute secret weapon, like last resort, I can't focus, I break this out.

That's how I use it; how do you use Pomodoros? 

[end of video]
caption: false

title: What if you're misdiagnosed? #adhd #shorts
description:
Transcription: 
Misdiagnosis can happen a lot with mental health conditions, and that's because different mental health conditions can have overlapping symptoms, sometimes there's more than one condition at play. It can get pretty complicated, so a really good thing to ask a Doctor who you feel may have misdiagnosed you is "Why this diagnosis? Why this and not something else?" or if they say "you don't have it", [ask] "Why not?". 

When I was twelve I was taken to a Doctor and he told my Mom that I couldn't have ADHD because I had gotten good grades in elementary school. That's a myth. You can be smart, you can get good grades, and still have ADHD.

So she knew to say "Thank you for your opinion, I'd like to see a specialist."

[EDIT] Thank you so much for your patience! Again, apologies for getting the transcription up late. 🧡
caption: false

title: Some of my Favorite Books that Help with My ADHD! #adhd #shorts #books
description:
Transcription: 

Some of my favourite books that help with my ADHD! 

"Set Boundaries Find Peace" (a guide to reclaiming yourself) by Nedra Glover Tawwab -- Simple guide to setting boundaries with clear examples of HOW

"Bird by Bird" (some instructions on writing and life) by Anne Lamott -- this book taught me how to write. It's hilarious! 

"Getting Ahead of ADHD"  (What next-generation science says about treatments that work -- and how you can make them work for your child) by Joel T. Nigg, PhD -- up-to-date info on what affects ADHD, written for parents by a brilliant researcher

"The Subtle Art of Not Giving A F*ck" (a counterintuitive approach to living a good life) by Mark Manson -- a surprisingly insightful, funny guide to handling adversity f*ck positivity! 

"The Skeptics Guide to the Universe" (how to know what's really real in a world increasingly full of fake) by Dr. Steven Novella -- taught me how often we humans get things wrong, why, and what to do about it 

"Why Will No One Play With Me?" (The play better plan to help children of all ages make friends and thrive) -- (I find a lot it helpful now) a book I wish my parents had read - how to help your kid make friends. 

Video ends with Jessica putting her hand in frame of the camera and giving us a thumbs up!

"The Subtle Art of Not Giving A F*ck" (a counterintuitive approach to living a good life) by Mark Manson -- a surprisingly insightful, funny guide to handling adversity f*ck positivity! 

"The Skeptics Guide to the Universe" (how to know what's really real in a world increasingly full of fake) by Dr. Steven Novella -- taught me how often we humans get things wrong, why, and what to do about it 

"Why Will No One Play With Me?" (The play better plan to help children of all ages make friends and thrive) -- (I find a lot it helpful now) a book I wish my parents had read - how to help your kid make friends. 

Video ends with Jessica putting her hand in frame of the camera and giving us a thumbs up!

title: What's an ADHD Toolbox? #adhd #shorts #hacks #mentalhealth #sensory #fidgets
description:
Transcription: 
On How to ADHD we talk about this metaphorical toolbox of tools that we use to support our brains but what about an actual toolbox and collecting items for it from a few different categories like Sensory Support, Physical Support, Mental Support. I will show you what's in my toolbox. 

So I have this blanket for sensory support -- I like the feeling of a cozy blanket around me when I'm anxious. I have animal crackers, I also have knitting which I can use to help me focus during meetings, and a glitter bottle to help me calm my emotional glitter. 

Let us know in the comments what's in yours!

title: Do You Have ADHD? or Depression? or Both? #shorts #adhd #depression #mentalhealth
description:
Transcription: 
When somebody has ADHD & depression the depression is considered either primary or secondary. Primary depression is a completely separate condition from ADHD. There isn't any internal or external events that trigger feelings of sadness and despair. There's often a family history of depression. Secondary depression is "because of" ADHD. It's due to years of low self-esteem, frustration, discouragement, because of living with untreated ADHD. It often occurs in teens and adults who's ADHD wasn't recognised and treated when they were younger. Who have come to accept the idea that they "aren't good enough", or they're "lazy", or "irresponsible". In either case, ADHD and Depression can exacerbate one another, so it's important to consider both in treatment.

title: What is it like having ADHD & Chronic Pain?
description:
When you have ADHD, it makes life hard. If you have chronic pain as well, it makes life just that much harder. It's already difficult for us to filter out distractions but for those of us with chronic pain, it's nearly impossible. For those of us who don't live with chronic pain though, what is it like?

Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Check out our website: http://howtoadhd.com

title: Handling Rumination/Thought Spirals: Tips on How to Cope With Self-Destructive Thoughts
description:
Those of us with ADHD (and especially Anxiety!) frequently have to deal with the unfortunate reality that are thought spirals. Today let's explore some community tips on how to cope with our brain's run away desire for rumination.

Check out OCD Stories' Podcast on Rumination!: 
https://open.spotify.com/episode/0dkcDzBZbBf3NZXExJEu7J?si=0f2776a9182f4590

What's emotional first aid? Why's it important? .... and how?? Check out these articles & tedtalk!: 
https://www.ted.com/talks/sangu_delle_there_s_no_shame_in_taking_care_of_your_mental_health?referrer=playlist-the_struggle_of_mental_health (Please note that Sangu uses imagery taken within Africa during his Tedtalk. If that imagery is going to be upsetting for you please take care to watch this at a time that is optimal for you and allows you to take care of yourself. 🧡) 
https://ideas.ted.com/7-ways-to-practice-emotional-first-aid/
https://www.urmc.rochester.edu/behavioral-health-partners/bhp-blog/september-2018/emotional-first-aid.aspx

Want to read the ideas we didn't include in the video? WE GOT YOU!: 
Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/post/Ugkx42Muv5QJPsxfFsSxSAgba-J6D0sqGvUz
Twitter: https://twitter.com/HowtoADHD/status/1519769866823094272?s=20&t=fn03STdYX3VtvxiiPt_vNA

title: What Makes Something "ADHD Friendly"?
description:
We live in a world designed for those who are Neurotypical, but when designing a world for those of us who have ADHD, we need to think about what it means to be "ADHD Friendly". So then, what does it mean to be "ADHD Friendly", and what makes it so?

Resources:
https://adhdfriendlylifestyle.com/
https://youtu.be/posZhu_YIl0
https://www.apartmenttherapy.com/tips-tricks-adhd-friendly-home-37044961?amp=1
https://totallyadd.com/adhd-friendly-house/
https://www.understood.org/en/articles/video-how-to-be-more-adhd-friendly
https://adhdatwork.add.org/adhd-friendly-technology-reviews/
https://askjan.org/disabilities/Attention-Deficit-Hyperactivity-Disorder-AD-HD.cfm?

title: Do You Have ADHD, Something Else, Or... Both?? (ft Comorbidities)
description:
Often while being diagnosed, we're told we have something other than ADHD due to our most visible symptoms. Things like anxiety, depression, dyslexia, autism, and more. Sometimes, that can be only HALF of the story... So the question is, do you have ADHD, something else, or both?

"Society for Developmental and Behavioral Pediatrics Clinical Practice Guideline for the Assessment and Treatment of Children and Adolescents with Complex Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder" Link: https://journals.lww.com/jrnldbp/Fulltext/2020/03001/Society_for_Developmental_and_Behavioral.3.aspx

localizations.es.description:
A menudo cuando estamos siendo diagnosticados, nos dicen que tenemos algo diferente al TDAH debido en parte a nuestros síntomas más visibles.  Cosas como la ansiendad, depresión, dislexia, autismo y muchas más. A veces esa puede ser sólo la MITAD de la historia...  Así que la pregunta es, ¿tienes TDAH, algo diferente, o ambos?

description:
Thank you to Sunsama for sponsoring this video! To try it out - use the link: https://get.sunsama.com/a/howtoadhd 

Masking is something those of us with ADHD do a lot, and usually without even realizing it, but what exactly is the problem with masking our ADHD and Autism?

title: How to Feed Yourself When You Have ADHD! - Executive Function Friendly Recipes
description:
Click my link https://mycopilot.me/how_to_ADHD and get your own CoPilot for over 20% off FOREVER ($99/mo instead of $129/mo) and a 14-day Free Trial!

Cooking can be such a struggle, ESPECIALLY if you have ADHD! That's why I reached out to the community and asked what are some of their go-to kind of foods that feel a bit easier, so you can learn how to feed yourself with some executive function friendly recipes when you have ADHD! 

Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Check out our website: http://howtoadhd.com

Follow us on all the things: 
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@howtoadhd
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/howtoadhd/
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd

Our Merch Shop: http://shop.howtoadhd.com

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
Recipe for DIY Teriyaki Sauce [for if you have a bit more executive function and want to try it]:
- 1/4 Cup Soy Sauce
- 1/2 Cup water 
- 2 tsp Minced garlic (you can use the jar of garlic)
- 1/2 tsp Ground ginger 
- 3 tbsp Honey 
- 1 tsp sesame oil
- 1 tbsp & 1 tsp Cornstarch 

In a small pot on medium-high heat, mix all ingredients except for cornstarch. Wait to boil, and stir occasionally.
In a separate bowl, mix cornstarch and 2 tbsp of cold water
Once the small pot with all ingredients is boiling, add in cornstarch mixture and stir until thickens. (It's like magic) 
Voila, Teriyaki sauce! And you can make more and store in the fridge for up to two weeks. How ADHD friendly!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

localizations.nl.description:
Klik op deze link https://mycopilot.me/how_to_ADHD voor je eigen CoPilot met 20% korting VOOR ALTIJD (88 Euro in plaats van 115 Euro per maand) en een gratis proefperiode van twee weken!

Koken kan moeilijk zijn, VOORAL als je ADHD hebt! Daarom vroeg ik de gemeenschap om makkelijke lievelingsrecepten. Zo leer je te koken met wat executieve functie-vriendelijke recepten!  

Steun ons op Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Check onze website: http://howtoadhd.com

Volg ons overal: 
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@howtoadhd
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/howtoadhd/
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd

Onze Merch Shop: http://shop.howtoadhd.com

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
Recept voor eigengemaakte Teriyaki Saus [om uit te proberen als je een goede brein-dag hebt!]:
- 60 ml sojasaus
- 120 ml water 
- 2 tl gehakte knoflook
- 1/2 tl gemberpoeder 
- 3 el honing 
- 1 tl sesamolie
- 1 el & 1 tl maizena 

Verhit de ingredienten onder af en toe roeren tot het kookpunt.
Mix de maizena en 2 el koud water in een kom.
Voeg dit toe aan de pan als deze kookt, roer tot de saus indikt.

Voila, Teriyaki saus! Deze is tot twee weken in de koelkast houdbaar. Heel ADHD-vriendelijk!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

title: How Dopamine Affects Learning and Motivation in ADHD Brains
description:
Thank you to Hero's Journal for sponsoring today's video! 
Go to https://theherosjournal.co/discount/howtoadhd and use code "howtoadhd" to try it out yourself.

Ever wondered what Dopamine was and how exactly it affects our brain? In this episode, we explore the wonderful world of dopamine and how it can affect our motivation and even our ability to learn!

Check out our website: http://howtoadhd.com

title: How to Get More Done (Feat. Monotasking)
description:
If you want to check out Wondrium, go to http://wondrium.com/howtoadhd to start your free trial today.

Getting things done is hard, but have you ever thought that the way we are taught to do things might not work for our brains? In this episode, we explore how "monotasking" works vs the traditional idea of "multitasking".

Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Check out our website: http://howtoadhd.com

Follow us on all the things: 
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@howtoadhd
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/howtoadhd/
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd

Our Merch Shop: http://shop.howtoadhd.com

Links! 
https://chadd.org/adhd-weekly/are-you-a-multitasker/
http://www.adhd-app.com/2013/07/05/multitasking-vs-monotasking-for-adhd/
https://www.additudemag.com/multitasking-with-adhd-productivity-fixes-at-work-and-home/
https://carlabirnberg.com/2013/03/04/the-power-of-mono-tasking/

Citations: 
May, K.E., Elder, A.D. (2018). Efficient, helpful, or distracting? A literature review of media multitasking in relation to academic performance. Int J Educ Technol High Educ, 15(13). https://doi.org/10.1186/s41239-018-0096-z 

Ophir, E., Nass, C., & Wagner, A. D. (2009). Cognitive control in media multitaskers. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 106(37), 15583–15587. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.0903620106

Carrier, L. M., Rosen, L. D., Cheever, N. A., & Lim, A. F. (2015). Causes, effects, and practicalities of everyday multitasking. Developmental Review, 35, 64-78. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dr.2014.12.005

title: What Does It Mean to Have "Burnout"?
description:
Burnout is a term that gets thrown around a lot -- and it's something those with ADHD are more susceptible to. But what exactly IS burnout? 

Research for this video provided by: Farah Mahmud
caption: true
localizations.en.title: What Does It Mean to Have "Burnout"?
localizations.en.description:
Burnout is a term that gets thrown around a lot -- and it's something those with ADHD are more susceptible to. But what exactly IS burnout?

localizations.de.title: Was bedeutet es, einen "Burnout" zu haben?
localizations.de.description:
Vielen Dank an Hero's Journal, dass sie das heutige Video sponsern!

Geht auf https://theherosjournal.co/discount/howtoadhd und benutzt den Code "howtoadhd", um es selbst auszuprobieren.

Es wird viel über Burnout geredet. Aber was heißt das eigentlich, einen Burnout zu haben? In diesem Video beantworten wir diese Frage!

QUELLEN zur Verfügung gestellt von: Farah Mahmud, M.S. Doctoral Candidate, Clinical Psychology 
Forschungsberater*innen: R. Boccamazzo, PsyD, Dr. Patrick LaCount

Zeitstempel:
1:48 - 2:15 Leiter, M.P. & Maslach, C. “Areas of Worklife: A Structured Approach to Organizational Predictors of Job Burnout,” in Research in Occupational Stress and Well-Being 3, eds. P.L. Perrewe & D.C. Ganster (Oxford: Elsevier, 2004): 91-134.
https://www.emerald.com/insight/content/doi/10.1016/S1479-3555(03)03003-8/full/html

1:03 - Tweet from one of the Brains: 
https://twitter.com/turtlecatpurrz/status/1414670363385008131

Weitere Quellen:

https://thriveglobal.com/stories/from-burnout-to-bonus-with-adhd-champion-peter-shankman/
https://www.additudemag.com/adhd-fatigue/
https://www.who.int/news/item/28-05-2019-burn-out-an-occupational-phenomenon-international-classification-of-diseases
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK279286/
https://twitter.com/TakeThisOrg/status/1442571430735060993
https://www.additudemag.com/adhd-at-work-adult-organized-stress-focus-executive-job-strategies/

localizations.hu.description:
Köszönet a Hero's Journalnak, hogy támogatták a mai videót!
Kattints a https://theherosjournal.co/discount/howtoadhd linkre és használd a "howtoadhd" kódot, hogy kipróbáld te is.

Az emberek sokat beszélnek a kiégésről. De mit jelent valójában a kiégés? Ebben a videóban megválaszoljuk ezt a kérdést!

A KUTATÁST biztosította: Farah Mahmud, M.S. Doctoral Candidate, Clinical Psychology
Szaktanácsadók: R. Boccamazzo, PsyD, Dr. Patrick LaCount

Idők:
1:48 - 2:15 Leiter, M.P. & Maslach, C. “Areas of Worklife: A Structured Approach to Organizational Predictors of Job Burnout,” in Research in Occupational Stress and Well-Being 3, eds. P.L. Perrewe & D.C. Ganster (Oxford: Elsevier, 2004): 91-134.

title: What if I Can't Tell What I'm Feeling? (Alexithymia)
description:
Thank you to BetterHelp for sponsoring this video. To receive 10% off your first month, visit: https://betterhelp.com/adhdhowto

Some people find it incredibly difficult to tell how they feel. Turns out, there's a term for this! Thank you @theedoctorb for inspiring & contributing to this video.

title: Why ADHD Brains Are So (HEY LOOK BALLOON!) Impulsive
description:
Thank you to Hero's Journal for sponsoring today's video! 
Go to https://theherosjournal.co/discount/howtoadhd and use code "howtoadhd" to try it out yourself. 

Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Check out our website: http://howtoadhd.com

Follow us on all the things: 
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@howtoadhd
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/howtoadhd/
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd

Our Merch Shop: http://shop.howtoadhd.com

Resource Links for "Why ADHD Brains Are (OH LOOK BALLOON!) Impulsive:
https://chadd.org/adhd-weekly/oops-that-was-impulsive/

Citations: 

ADHD-related impairment can arise from a core deficit in response inhibition
Barkley, R. A. (1997). Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, self- regulation, and time: Toward a more comprehensive theory. Journal of Developmental and Behavioral Pediatrics, 18, 271–279. 

A meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies found consistent underactivation in frontostriatal circuit among those with ADHD durings tasks require response inhibition 
Dickstein, S. G., Bannon, K., Castellanos, F. X., & Milham, M. P. (2006). The neural correlates of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: An ALE meta-analysis. Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry and Allied Disciplines, 47, 1051–1062. 

Research Provided By: Farah Mahmud & Dr. Patrick LaCount

title: Does Having ADHD Make You More Creative?
description:
Those with ADHD often hear that it makes us more creative. Does it? And how? And if so, why can't I finish knitting a scarf? ADD TO THE MIND MAP! http://bit.ly/creativitymindmap

Need a blank mind map? We made a worksheet here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1A3Y6AYwir-TLxoCeWgnKupUWZZC_fEJq/view

Wanna know what apps showed up at 5:58?  We got you!: 
Top: Brili, Slack, Trello 
Middle: Monday, Owaves
Bottom: MindMeister

Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Check out our website: http://howtoadhd.com

Follow us on all the things: 
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@howtoadhd
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/howtoadhd/
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd

Our Merch Shop: http://shop.howtoadhd.com

RESEARCH:
Research for this video provided by: Farah Mahmud  
(**edit: some citations in the video are missing, but all reference links are listed below):
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-creativity-of-adhd/
https://doi.org/10.1002/jocb.382
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2017.03.050
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2010.12.015
https://doi.org/10.1177/1087054717727352
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neubiorev.2020.09.029
https://chadd.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/ATTN_08_12_MindMapping.pdf

DIVERGENT THINKING explained in a mind map: https://thinkdivergent.io/share/blueprint/57a96e4a3a5d4940b23803c03cb38706


Music for "Does Having ADHD Make You More Creative?"
"The Show Must Be Go”
Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com)
Licensed under Creative Commons: By Attribution 3.0
http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/

title: ADHD and Emotions: How Mindfulness Can Help (& 3 Questions to Ask!)
description:
Emotions can be intense when you have ADHD. Mindfulness can help.

title: Digital Brain Timer for Getting Projects Done!
description:
Use our "Brain Timers" to help you get your tasks done! There are three to chose from:

A short brain timer for when you’re having trouble focusing. (10 minutes focused / 3 minutes break): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vb_f1K5cDK8
A typical brain timer. (25 minutes focused / 5 minutes break): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N02eoAC7MH4
And a long brain timer for projects where you want to get into the flow. (45 minutes focused / 15 minutes break): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zdGlv_ydJPg

title: Exploring how my psychiatric service dog can help with ADHD and Anxiety
description:
Chloe and I begin working with a trainer. Follow our journey: @servicedaug (Insta, Twitter)
For more on grief: https://whatsyourgrief.com/ https://widowedparent.org/
To work with Chris (they/them): http://hetlinger.pro (service dogs require some in person sessions, but Chris can work completely remotely for other types of training -- emotional support animals are great for ADHD, too!!) 
For more on service animals: https://www.ada.gov/regs2010/service_animal_qa.html
For more on the social model of disability: https://youtu.be/0e24rfTZ2CQ
https://www.afdo.org.au/social-model-of-disability/

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

title: Why Stimulant Medication Helps ADHD -- and How Stigma Can Hurt
description:
Happy ADHD Awareness Month! In honor of that, and hitting half a million subscribers (eeee!!!), I decided to ask Dr. Carolyn Lentzch-Parcells (www.gtw-health.com) to come talk about stimulant medication -- and help bust some of the stigma that keeps people from treating their ADHD. 

#ADHD #treatment #stigma 
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

title: Dealing with Grief -- How to Replace what You've Lost
description:
When I got home for the first time after losing my mom, I didn't do anything I expected. Here's what I did instead -- and why. 

Also, as we've seen this week, anyone can get COVID -- including those in the White House. Here's how we can protect ourselves, those we love, and the loved ones of people we've never even met. 

#grief #ADHD #dog

title: ADHD Friendly Way to Plan Your Day -- Owaves Review! (iOS)
description:
Planning and prioritizing can be quite a challenge for ADHD Brains -- so when our external structure falls apart (heyyy, COVID...) we often need a lil help rebuilding. This video, I partnered with Owaves (https://owaves.com/howtoadhd) to show you their incredibly ADHD friendly app on iOS, which makes it easy to visually structure our day -- and their new feature "My Moai" lets us connect with others to see their day, too! 

How to download: 
Go to https://Owaves.com/HowtoADHD
Download Test Flight

title: 90 Day Accountability Challenge -- Join Me!
description:
This was something I decided to do on impulse (yay ADHD!) but thought could be really fun and helpful. It's based on the concept of no zero days (http://bit.ly/no0days) -- even if we don't have time to do much, doing *something* toward our goals every day can help us get into the habits that support our progress in the areas that are important to us. #challenge 
#progress 

PRINTABLE STICKER CHART to help us remember to do something every day:
http://bit.ly/90dayskillchallenge

EMAIL TO SEND VIDEOS TO: Progress@HowtoADHD.com 

DEADLINE: To be included in the video -- 
email FIRST video by Monday, September 21st, 2020; 
submit FINAL video by December 21st, 2020, at midnight PST. 

INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Record a video of you performing a skill you want to improve
2. Send the video to: Progress@HowtoADHD.com (by September 21st)
3. Practice that skill every day for 90 days (printable sticker chart to help you keep track: http://bit.ly/90dayskillchallenge )
4. Record another video after 90 days to show your progress and send that video to: Progress@HowtoADHD.com (by December 21st)

FAQ: 
Q: I missed a day. Can I still submit a video? 
A: Yeah! The goal is to have no zero days, meaning to do at least a *little* every day, but hi we have ADHD. Try to get 90 days in but if you miss a few days just let us know in the final video how many days you practiced :) 

Q: I saw this vlog after the first deadline or forgot to do it in time. Can I still submit a video?
A: Yeah! If this is helpful for people we may do it again, so go ahead and start whenever. The deadlines are just to be included in the video we're making for the end of the year. 

Q: I have a question about this challenge that isn't answered here. Uh....
A: use # FAQ and ask your question. If it's appropriate for the FAQ, I'll add it when I see it :)
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

tags: ['deal']
title: How to Deal with Rejection Sensitivity
description:
This is my most requested episode ever. Thanks to the support of my research team, creative team, professional consultants, and the fabulous Caroline Maguire, it's finally done :) Enjoy!!!
FREE PRINTABLE REFERENCE CARD: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1oncdgtsFqd1jWrkqAjqD9xCjT9SQk0_n/view?usp=sharing
(it fits great in a bullet journal, or fold it to stick in a wallet!)

CHECK OUT DANI'S COGNITIVE DISTORTIONS: 
https://www.adhddd.com/shop/the-faces-of-cognitive-distortions/

GET CAROLINE'S BOOK: 
https://www.carolinemaguireauthor.com/

Caroline Maguire, M.Ed., ACCG, PCC founded and facilitates a comprehensive SEL training methodology (#ConnectionMatters) for adults, parents, clinicians and academic professionals on how to develop critical social, emotional and behavioral skills, in themselves and in others. Caroline’s book Why Will No One Play With Me?  is a playbook that includes foolproof scripts on how to communicate – with anyone, in any situation – and how to ensure the message registers with the recipient – no small task! Through her private practice, publications, lectures and workshops, her mission is to vanquish the devastating effects of feeling different and misunderstood. 

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

localizations.en.title: How to Deal with Rejection Sensitivity
localizations.en.description:
This is my most requested episode ever. Thanks to the support of my research team, creative team, professional consultants, and the fabulous Caroline Maguire, it's finally done :) Enjoy!!!
FREE PRINTABLE REFERENCE CARD: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1oncdgtsFqd1jWrkqAjqD9xCjT9SQk0_n/view?usp=sharing
(it fits great in a bullet journal, or fold it to stick in a wallet!)

CHECK OUT DANI'S COGNITIVE DISTORTIONS: 
https://www.adhddd.com/shop/the-faces-of-cognitive-distortions/

GET CAROLINE'S BOOK: 
https://www.carolinemaguireauthor.com/

Caroline Maguire, M.Ed., ACCG, PCC founded and facilitates a comprehensive SEL training methodology (#ConnectionMatters) for adults, parents, clinicians and academic professionals on how to develop critical social, emotional and behavioral skills, in themselves and in others. Caroline’s book Why Will No One Play With Me?  is a playbook that includes foolproof scripts on how to communicate – with anyone, in any situation – and how to ensure the message registers with the recipient – no small task! Through her private practice, publications, lectures and workshops, her mission is to vanquish the devastating effects of feeling different and misunderstood. 

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

title: How ADHD Treatment Is Not ADHD Friendly
description:
I wasn't sure if I was going to share this because it's very raw and personal, but I decided it's important to. If you resonate, comment. Share. Let's let others with ADHD know they're not alone in this struggle and help mental health professionals understand what we go through. Let's make some change.

title: What It's Like to Be ADHD and Black
description:
There are many factors that affect our lived experience of ADHD. This is the first in a series of videos that will explore what it's like to be ADHD *and.* Given what's going on in this country, I thought it was important to start with what it's like to be ADHD and Black. 

00:00 Intro
01:57 Meet The Brains
05:42 Mental Health And The Black Community
10:00 Masking and Code-Switching
12:32 Dealing With Discrimination
19:09 Moving Forward
24:04 Outro
25:03 Endcard

LINKS (in order of introduction): 

Romanza McAllister, LCSW Social Action Influencer 
ADHD Coach & Race Equity Advocate 
http://mcallisterpsychotherapy.com/
--
Diyah Najah
Artist & Educator
www.ArtistDiyahNajah.com IG:@ArtistDiyahNajah

title: How to Give Your Brain the Stimulation It Needs
description:
The things we tend to do when we're bored often don't give our brains the level of stimulation they need. Here's how to make a dopa-menu full of things that do! 
Check out more from Eric Tivers here: https://www.ADHDreWired.com/
Link to "ADHD and Boredom": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CaG5XjyWc8c

description:

If you need support, check out this list of mental health resources: https://www.takethis.org/mental-health-resources/

title: ADHD and Boredom
description:
Hello brains! Being stuck at home during a global pandemic, there's a good chance we're getting bored...and when we get bored, we don't always make the best choices. Here's a simple mindfulness tool that can help. 

#stayhome 

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

CONSULTANTS FOR THIS VIDEO: 
Patrick A. LaCount, PhD
Eric Tivers, LCSW
Raffael Boccamazzo, PsyD ("Dr. B")
Vitea "V" Medici

V. also made a list of *all* the sources that were used while making this video and we’ll try to keep this up for all future videos as well!

DISCLAIMER: The inclusion of a source does not equal agreement with everything that source does. The list provided below consists of *all* sources that were read/consulted to research and make this video.

STUDIES:

Blum, K., Chen, A. L., Braverman, E. R., Comings, D. E., Chen, T. J., Arcuri, V., Blum, S. H., Downs, B. W., Waite, R. L., Notaro, A., Lubar, J., Williams, L., Prihoda, T. J., Palomo, T., & Oscar-Berman, M. (2008). Attention-deficit-hyperactivity disorder and reward deficiency syndrome. Neuropsychiatric disease and treatment, 4(5), 893–918. https://doi.org/10.2147/ndt.s2627

Hunter, A., Eastwood, J.D. Does state boredom cause failures of attention? Examining the relations between trait boredom, state boredom, and sustained attention. Exp Brain Res 236, 2483–2492 (2018). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00221-016-4749-7

Malkovsky, E., Merrifield, C., Goldberg, Y. et al. Exploring the relationship between boredom and sustained attention. Exp Brain Res 221, 59–67 (2012). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00221-012-3147-z

Barnes, J. J., Dean, A. J., Nandam, L. S., Oconnell, R. G., & Bellgrove, M. A. (2011). The Molecular Genetics of Executive Function: Role of Monoamine System Genes. Biological Psychiatry, 69(12). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.biopsych.2010.12.040 


ARTICLES: 
https://www.verywellmind.com/adhd-and-boredom-20493
http://cogbtherapy.com/mindfulness-meditation-blog/mindfulness-stop-skill
https://www.additudemag.com/boredom-at-work-with-adhd/
https://psychcentral.com/blog/adhd-and-adults-helpful-tips-for-beating-boredom/
https://www.amenclinics.com/blog/boredom-in-adhd/
https://www.additudemag.com/inside-the-add-mind/

BOOKS: 
Mann, S. (2016). The Science of Boredom: Why Boredom is Good. London: Robinson.

title: How to Make a Stay at Home Plan During the Crisis
description:
Parents! A lot of you have expressed having a hard time transitioning to working from home while also trying to homeschool your kids. I've been listening to your questions and brought them to Brendan Mahan, M.Ed, M.S. of ADHD Essentials.  http://ADHDessentials.com 

Here, he talks about how to create a stay-at-home plan that actually works. I think it's actually a useful way to plan in general when you have ADHD! 

THE PDF: 
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gviz3PoANMHcESFohJpJ-N1mlTKwGEFp0jGE3p07JmA/edit?usp=sharing

#stayhome 

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

title: ADHD and Motivation
description:
Hello Brains! Having trouble Doing the Thing? You're not alone. Motivation is one of the biggest challenges most ADHDers face. This episode is all about how to fix Motivation Bridge. 

Special thanks to Doctor B from TakeThis.org for coming up with the clever phrase "fill in the planks" -- and for motivating me in so many ways.  

And of course, a giant thank you to my brilliant editors and animators Palestrina and JustCallMeGary for working tirelessly to help me bring Motivation Bridge to life (and making me cry). You should...you should sleep now.

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

#ADHD #Motivation
localizations.de.title: ADHS und Motivation
localizations.de.description:
Hallo Brains! Habt ihr Schwierigkeiten, das Ding zu tun? Ihr seid nicht alleine. Motivation ist eine der größten Hürden, denen die meisten ADHSler gegenüber stehen. Diese Folge behandelt umfassend, wie man die Motivationsbrücke repariert.

Besonderen Dank an Doctor B von TakeThis.org für den cleveren Einfall, den Begriff "die planken verlegen" ("fill in the planks") einzuführen -- und dafür, dass er mich auf so viele Arten motiviert.

Und natürlich, ein Riesendank an meine herausragenden Editor*innen und Animator*innen Palestrina und JustCallMeGary für ihren unermüdlichen Einsatz dabei, die Motivationsbrücke zum Leben zu erwecken (und mich zum Weinen zu bringen). Ihr solltet... Ihr solltet jetzt schlafen.

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

localizations.nl.title: ADHD en Motivatie
localizations.nl.description:
Hallo Brains! Heb je moeite met Het Ding Doen? Je bent niet de enige. Motivatie is een van de grootste uitdagingen voor de meeste ADHD'ers. Deze aflevering gaat over hoe je de "motivatie-brug" kunt repareren. 

Met speciale dank aan Doctor B van TakeThis.org voor het bedenken van de zin "vul de planken aan" en de manier waarop ik op zoveel manieren gemotiveerd raak.

En natuurlijk, super bedankt aan mijn briljante editor en animator, Palestrina en JustCallMeGary, voor het onvermoeid werken om deze aflevering werkelijkhied te maken (en me tot tranen te brengen). Jullie moeten... jullie moeten nu maar gaan slapen.

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Steun ons op Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

WE HEBBEN EEN LIED GEMAAKT!!
Luister naar “The Fish Song” op... 
...iTunes: http://bit.ly/fishsongitunes
...Google Music: http://bit.ly/fishsonggp
...Amazon: http://bit.ly/fishsongamazon


"The Show Must Be Go”, “Carefree”, “Life of Riley”, “Bittersweet”

#ADHD #Motivation
localizations.sv.title: ADHD och Motivation
localizations.sv.description:
Hej Brains! ("Hjärnor") Har du problem att få gjort den där grejen? Du är inte ensam. Motivation är en av de största utmaningarna som personer med ADHD ställs inför. Det här avsnittet handlar om hur man fixar Motivations Bron.

Speciellt tack till Doctor B från TakeThis.org för att ha hittat på frasen "fill in the planks" -- och för all motivation han ger.

Och förstås, ett stort tack till mina briljanta redigerare och animatörer Palestrina and JustCallMeGary för att ni jobbar outtröttligt för att hjälpa mig väcka liv i Motivations-Bron (och för att ni fick mig till tårar). Ni borde... ni borde sova nu.

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

title: How to Avoid Impulse Spending When You Have ADHD
description:
Spending money is fun -- as long as you meant to spend it and don't need it for things like, I dunno...rent. Holiday survival workbook: https://rena-fi.com/the-adhd-holiday-survival-guide-for-your-wallet/

I'm pretty impulsive myself, especially around Christmas -- so I reached out to Rena-fi for tips on how to avoid emotional spending during the holidays. 

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Check out our Holiday merch shop! ▶ https://shop.spreadshirt.com/how-to-adhd

title: What “Into the Woods” Taught Me About Change
description:
Hello Brains! This is a vlog style video, I wanted to get a bit more intimate than usual and talk about how I'm doing personally as well as share some things I learned from "Into the Woods" about how to deal with change, loss, and the grief that comes with it. It was really helpful for me, hope it helps you too. ♥️

****If you're in crisis, text CONNECT to 741741**** 

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

WE WROTE A SONG!!
Get the “The Fish Song” on... 
...iTunes: http://bit.ly/fishsongitunes
...Google Music: http://bit.ly/fishsonggp
...Amazon: http://bit.ly/fishsongamazon


LINKS:

Grief vs. Depression: https://www.verywellmind.com/grief-and-depression-1067237


Excerpt from the video: 

"When something big changes, there’s this desire to figure out why it happened and whose fault it is, and retracing your steps and their steps and placing blame but the truth is it’s never one person’s fault, it’s always a joint effort 

and the fact is no matter how you ended up here, you’re here -- 

and suddenly the way isn’t clear, the light isn’t good, and none of the paths look familiar. 

Suddenly the story you’re in doesn’t make sense. 

The narrator is gone. 

And you find yourself lost in the woods with no way back to the life you knew. 

When this happens, you might be angry — at other people, at yourself, at the woods — 

you might try to bargain with them, you might try to pretend everything’s fine and nothing has changed, 

you might want to give up and leave the woods entirely.  

You might feel like you’re not cut out to handle any of this and have no idea how you’re going to make it through.  

That’s grief. 

And that’s what I’ve been dealing with. 

Accepting that my life isn’t the same anymore has been really challenging for me. 

Letting go of what I had, what I would have had. 

Starting over when I thought I’d never have to again. Even though I chose to leave, I didn’t choose the reasons I felt I had to. 

And dealing with this grief has brought up a lot of past grief, a lot of loss, 

my grandparents, my dad, important people that have guided me in the past and aren’t around to anymore.  

Sometimes my grief feels like it might be slipping into depression, because I feel useless and there’s a part of me that doesn’t care, that doesn’t see how getting through the woods even matters, because I’ve lost the thread of why I’m even here, what my place is in this story. 

A few takeaways that I really love from Into the Woods though were this — 

1. No one is alone, and even those who aren’t around anymore can still guide us

2. Even when things don’t go the way we want, we learn things, we gain resources. We’re never really starting over. 

3. And when we have no idea where to start and we’re daunted by it all to the point that we’re ready to give up, we can start with the small actions we can take. 

The father left alone to raise a child could start with “calm the child.” 

I can start with “talk about grief.” 

It’s going to take me time to make sense of my life again. 

And after the emotional earthquake I’ve gone through I can’t move through the woods as quickly as I’m used to, which is really frustrating. 

But there are actions I can take. 

It isn’t hopeless. 

I can’t have the life I knew, but I can build a new one.  

It won’t be the same, but it doesn’t have to be the same to be good. 

And while the woods aren’t as friendly a place for me as they used to be, I don’t have to face them alone.

None of us do.  

Thank you, Brains. 







What "Into the Woods" Taught Me About Change

Thank you, Brains.

title: 5 Tips to Make Assertive Communication Easier and More Effective
description:
Hello Brains! I’m obsessed with assertive communication right now because it’s a super effective way to express our needs while actually *Improving* our relationships. It’s a win/win. Seriously. THIS. CHANGES. EVERYTHING.

But actually practicing assertive communication can be hard. Here are some helpful tips!

Last episode: 
“Why People Pleasing Doesn’t Make People Happy”
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BanqlGZSWiI

TEDx talk I mentioned: https://www.ted.com/talks/adam_galinsky_how_to_speak_up_for_yourself/transcript?language=en

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

WE WROTE A SONG!!
Get the “The Fish Song” on... 
...iTunes: http://bit.ly/fishsongitunes
...Google Music: http://bit.ly/fishsonggp
...Amazon: http://bit.ly/fishsongamazon

Assertive communication is clearly and honestly expressing our feelings and needs, while respecting the feelings and needs of the other person. 

"The Show Must Be Go”
Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com)
Licensed under Creative Commons: By Attribution 3.0
http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/
caption: false
localizations.en.title: 5 Tips to Make Assertive Communication Easier and More Effective
localizations.en.description:
Hello Brains! I’m obsessed with assertive communication right now because it’s a super effective way to express our needs while actually *Improving* our relationships. It’s a win/win. Seriously. THIS. CHANGES. EVERYTHING.

But actually practicing assertive communication can be hard. Here are some helpful tips!

Last episode: 
“Why People Pleasing Doesn’t Make People Happy”
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BanqlGZSWiI

TEDx talk I mentioned: https://www.ted.com/talks/adam_galinsky_how_to_speak_up_for_yourself/transcript?language=en

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Special thanks to Bob Morrissey for bringing me out to speak and being so gracious about the technical difficulties!!!

title: How to Do The Thing! A Pep Talk! ...no. SONG!
description:
Hello Brains!

Okay, so, appaaaarently it wasn't enough to just WRITE the song...I also had to learn it, record it, shoot like 68 scenes of me doing things you said you'd do...3 weeks later, ENJOY!!! Hope you like it!
(If it gets annoying, you can turn it off as soon as you do the thing ;) )

Capo 3

G  
Hello Brains! For this New Year
  D
I wrote a silly song for you 
  Em
To encourage and annoy you into 
D
Doing things you said you’d do 

—
150 BPM
G     
Brush your hair, make your bed 
D
Get a job that you don’t hate 
Em
Practice cursive every day 
Bm  D
Don’t forget to meditate

G
Actually get out of bed
D
and be less self deprecating
A
Use a pomodoro timer 
D
Spend 5 hours animating

G
Say some mantras, do some pull-ups
D
Exercise your chest and core
Em
Be more honest ‘bout your feelings 
Bm    D
Take yourself to movies more

G
Only eat out once a month
D
Write 3 pages every day
A
Get to sleep before midnight
D
Play piano on Tuesdays 

—

Bridge:

G
Goals can be intimidating
Am      D
Falling short can be frustrating
A
But here’s a simple Brain-proof method 
D                           D7
That I’ll share with you 

—
CHORUS:

Super cheery, 170 BPM
        G
Do it badly 
        D
Do it terribly
C                            D
Write 3 pages that no one would read 
                G                              D
You have so many reasons to do these things
       A     D
And none of you said you’d do them perfectlyyyyy

So --

G
Get a ukulele, play it, 
D
Use your planner every day
Em
Dance like no one’s watching you
Bm    D
Do your laundry every Sunday (alt: on Sundays)
 Opt:Read your bible, keep the faith
G
Pack your bag and pick out clothes
D
The night before so you’re not late
A
Exercise 3 days a week 
D
Sing cause it makes choir way…
Easier…

G
Practice oboe, do your push-ups
D
Brush your teeth and wash your face
Em
Ignore your phone until you’re ready
Bm  D
So you don’t procrastinate 

G
Drink some water, take a selfie 
D
And do not forget to eat 
A
Wash the dishes every night 
D
Program at least twice a week 

And
        G
Do it badly 
        D
Do it terribly
C       D
Take a selfie that no one will see 
     G     D
You have so many reasons to do these things
                 A     D
Way more important than doing them perfectlyyyyy

So 

G
Stick to the routines you’ve built;
            D
Reach out to friends and family
Em
Write a little every day.
Bm  D
So you’ll finish that book, Leigh!

G
Work before your boyfriend gets home 
D
Take an hour just for you 
A
Pray and read devotionals
D
walk 10 minutes, hula hoop 

G
Do your homework after school and
D
Get rid of toxicity.
Em
Adventure every Thursday so you 
Bm    D
Don’t resent all your routines — 

G
Take your meds, draw before bed
D
Walk up 8 whole flights of stairs  
A
Daily coding challenges and 
D
Be more present with your kids

And
         G
Do it badly
         D
Do it terribly 
C  D
Code a solution that won’t work gen’rally
     G     D
You have so many reasons to do these things
 A    D
And seriously, please don’t do them perfectly —

Hello Brains!

Okay, so, appaaaarently it wasn't enough to just WRITE the song...I also had to learn it, record it, shoot like 68 scenes of me doing things you said you'd do...3 weeks later, ENJOY!!! Hope you like it!
(If it gets annoying, you can turn it off as soon as you do the thing ;) )

title: ADD? ADHD? ...TDAH?! What are we supposed to be calling this thing?
description:
The name ADHD has evolved over the years and is even different from country to country. It gets confusing! So incredi-brain Charles Chung helped us create this episode investigating what ADHD is called all around the world. Special thank to Charles and to all the international brains who submitted videos! 

**oops, we misspelled one! Katsiaryna Shylenka.is the Brain from Belarus! 

If you'd like to submit a video, check out the link below and email it to our special collab email (address: howtoadhd+me@gmail.com) 

http://bit.ly/2OHv61y



videos mentioned:

history of ADHD (and emotional dysregulation): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2kew2JhKq3Y&t=84s

Am I Lazy, Stupid, Messy, Flaky? ADHD: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rUsotGVqUy4&t=3s

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Connect with other ADHD brains and hearts on our forums:
http://forums.howtoadhd.com
Or on Discord (you'll get a link when you sign up for Patreon):
http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

title: Am I Lazy, Stupid, Messy, Flaky? ADHD
description:
Hello brains and hearts!

ADHD can be challenging enough, but the stigma surrounding it can sometimes be worse. We're labeled "lazy," "stupid," "messy," "flaky," and a lot more - sometimes by people we respect.  Sometimes we label ourselves.  What it all comes down to is "shame."

When everyone around you is doubting you, it's really hard not to doubt yourself.  Here's how to cope. 

(spoiler: sometimes one of the best tools we have is each other)


LINKS!

2018 International Conference on ADHD
http://bit.ly/2NqXAar

Get tickets for the 2018 International Conference here! (I'm speaking on Sunday!)
http://bit.ly/2QDJoNt

If you're in Auckland, New Zealand on October 13, 2018, come see me speak for ADHD Awareness Day!  
http://bit.ly/2Nt4qMq

Get your tickets here!
http://bit.ly/NZADHD2018

Visit our forums!
http://forums.howtoadhd.com

localizations.en.description:
Hello brains and hearts!

ADHD can be challenging enough, but the stigma surrounding it can sometimes be worse. We're labeled "lazy," "stupid," "messy," "flaky," and a lot more - sometimes by people we respect.  Sometimes we label ourselves.  What it all comes down to is "shame."

When everyone around you is doubting you, it's really hard not to doubt yourself.  Here's how to cope. 

(spoiler: sometimes one of the best tools we have is each other)


LINKS!

2018 International Conference on ADHD
http://bit.ly/2NqXAar

Get tickets for the 2018 International Conference here! (I'm speaking on Sunday!)
http://bit.ly/2QDJoNt

If you're in Auckland, New Zealand on October 13, 2018, come see me speak for ADHD Awareness Day!  
http://bit.ly/2Nt4qMq

Get your tickets here!
http://bit.ly/NZADHD2018

Visit our forums!
http://forums.howtoadhd.com


-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Connect with other ADHD brains and hearts on our forums:
http://forums.howtoadhd.com

WE WROTE A SONG!!
Get the “The Fish Song” on... 
...iTunes: http://bit.ly/fishsongitunes
...Google Music: http://bit.ly/fishsonggp
...Amazon: http://bit.ly/fishsongamazon


"The Show Must Be Go”, “Carefree”, “Life of Riley”, “Bittersweet”
Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com)
Licensed under Creative Commons: By Attribution 3.0
http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/

“The Future Begins Today” 
by Brett Van Donsel
localizations.zh-TW.title: 我懶惰、笨、亂七八糟、不靠譜嗎？ADHD注意力不足過動症
localizations.zh-TW.description:
哈囉！腦腦們和心心們！

身為ADHD患者的挑戰已經有夠大了，但對周遭對ADHD的汙名化讓一切更加糟糕。我們常被貼上「懶惰」、「笨」、「亂七八糟」、「不靠譜」等一大堆標籤，有時還是被我們敬仰的人貼上的，有時我們也會給我們自己貼標籤，一切都是因為「羞恥感」。

當你身邊的每個人都懷疑你時，很難不懷疑自己。這支影片教你如何應對。

（爆雷：有時候我們擁有的最好的工具之一就是彼此）

相關連結
2018 International Conference on ADHD
http://bit.ly/2NqXAar

2018 International Conference 訂票連結 (我週日上場)
http://bit.ly/2QDJoNt

如果你在2018年10月13日在紐西蘭的奧克蘭，請來看我為ADHD意識日發言！
http://bit.ly/2Nt4qMq

訂票連結
http://bit.ly/NZADHD2018

我們的論壇
http://forums.howtoadhd.com


-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
到 Patreon 支持我們: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

在我們的論壇上與其他ADHD腦腦和心心聯繫:
http://forums.howtoadhd.com

我們寫了一首歌 “The Fish Song” 
想聽可以到這裡...
...iTunes: http://bit.ly/fishsongitunes
...Google Music: http://bit.ly/fishsonggp
...Amazon: http://bit.ly/fishsongamazon

title: To the Teachers of ADHD Students (How Can I Help?)
description:
Hello Teachers of Brains! 

I know you’re out there in the classroom every day, overwhelmed with the number of students/lesson plans/IEPs/504 plans/etc. etc. etc. you have to worry about -- I’m not here to add to your plate, I’d like to make it easier. Your ADHD students need you, whether or not they’ve been diagnosed -- let me know how I can help.  Happy back to school!

(Classroom-friendly!) Fidgets: 
https://www.fidgetland.com/product/noah
https://www.tanglecreations.com/collections/all
https://www.boinks.com/

Posters:
An all-brains-appropriate version of our "you are not alone" poster: **technical difficulties uploading this, please check back after Edward gets some sleep**

The iceberg animation was based off a poster from ADDitude Magazine.  You can find it here: http://bit.ly/2MLEUGe

This is what it's really like to have ADHD: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ji0hg1LduU8&vl=en

"Failing at Normal: An ADHD Success Story" – My TEDx talk: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JiwZQNYlGQI

Understood through your child’s eyes tool: 
https://u.org/2Jwj2tz

title: How to (Actually) Help Someone Who's Depressed
description:
It can be hard to watch someone you care about struggle with depression, especially when nothing you say seems to make a difference. Here's how to (actually) help.

Connect with us:
Facebook: facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: twitter.com/howtoadhd
Forums: howtoadhd.com/forums
Support us on Patreon: patreon.com/howtoadhd

People who take their lives don't want to die—they just want to stop hurting.

How to help: 

https://www.helpguide.org/articles/suicide-prevention/suicide-prevention.htm
How to be a friend: http://www.takethis.org/expert-advice/how-to-be-a-friend/
Preventing suicide: https://www.nami.org/Find-Support/Family-Members-and-Caregivers/Preventing-Suicide
https://thebestschools.org/magazine/vigilant-against-teen-suicide/
https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/suicide-prevention/warning-signs.html

If you have a friend or family member that's been dealing with depression and you suddenly see an upswing in their mood, pay close attention. Signs of suicide are an abrupt sense of calm, giving gifts and personal possessions (especially valuable items or items of personal significance/sentimental value). 

The most important thing you can do if you're feeling suicidal is to tell someone. These numbers are free, confidential and avail 24/7:
Call: 800-273-TALK (8255)
Text: HOME to 741741 

International numbers: http://suicide.org/international-suicide-hotlines.html

LINKS:

Take This: http://www.takethis.org/expert-advice/what-is-depression/ 
Doctor B: http://twitter.com/theedoctorb

The Facebook post of what works for this tribe: https://www.facebook.com/howtoadhd/posts/646410659056

Connect with us:
Twitter: twitter.com/howtoadhd
Facebook: facebook.com/howtoadhd
Forums: howtoadhd.com/forums
Support us on Patreon: patreon.com/howtoadhd

LINKS:

Music playlists of songs that work for brains when they're down:
http://bit.ly/MusicAlltheFeels
http://bit.ly/MusicAlltheHope
http://bit.ly/MusicAlltheSmiles

Suicide:
https://save.org/about-suicide/
https://afsp.org/about-suicide/
https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/suicide-factsheet.pdf
https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org
https://suicideprevention.ca
https://www.iasp.info/resources/index.php
http://www.yourlifecounts.org/need-help/crisis-lines
https://kidshelpphone.ca
https://www.verywellmind.com/why-do-people-commit-suicide-1067515

What is depression? 
https://www.nami.org/Learn-More/Mental-Health-Conditions/Depression
http://www.takethis.org/expert-advice/what-is-depression/
(video) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XiCrniLQGYc
https://www.mentalhealthamerica.net/sites/default/files/Life%20with%20Depression%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf

title: 3 Tips to Make Packing for a Trip Less Stressful
description:
Traveling is fun!  

Throwing your entire hamper into a suitcase at the last minute and racing to the airport, learning your suitcase is 10 pounds over the limit and having to board a plane wearing 15 layers of clothes only to get to your destination and realize you forgot the one thing you ACTUALLY WANTED TO WEAR is not. 

These tips can help! 

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

title: VIDCON 2018 Vlog Day 2 -- Ft. The ReVibe!
description:
If you want to get a Revibe for yourself, they have a 90-day money back guarantee with free shipping – AND – if you enter the code "15fence" at checkout, you'll get $15 off your order! 
Http://revibetech.com


VidCon 2018 Vlog Day 2: we managed to find a snag of time in between panels and madness to record this!  Another awesome meetup (I forgot my ukelele today, so we just did a fun trivia game and gave away stickers and T-shirts). 

MOAR PRIZES MORE WINNERS AUGGHHHH 
(if you won a ReVibe , we'll be reaching out to you once we get home from VidCon!)

If you want to enter to win a prize in our FINAL giveaway (five winners will be picked!) comment below with the most important thing (to you) that you learned from watching the channel.  Tag it with #Day3, and post it before 1pm Pacific on Saturday, June 23, and you just might win one of the awesome things we have. :D

Congratulations to the winners of the Revibe!  We will be contacting you soon about getting your information.

If you want to get a Revibe for yourself, they have a 90-day money back guarantee with free shipping – AND – if you enter the code "15fence" at checkout, you'll get $15 off your order! 
Http://revibetech.com

Thanks to Fokuslabs for providing the Revibes for today's giveaway!

(We didn't receive any monetary compensation for any of these giveaways)

And thanks to our volunteer Gary (?) for helping out, check out his comics here! http://justcallmegary.com

title: VidCon 2018 Day 1 Vlog + Winner Announcement!!!
description:
Hi brains!

The awesome winners of the #Day1 joke contest are:

Decorum Morti
JasJules
SarahDidAYouTubeThing

Congratulations, winners!  Check your YouTube messages soon after VidCon for more information on how to receive your prize.  

For Day 2's entrants: 

If you already entered a joke using #Day1 on our announcement video, you're already entered! If you haven't had a chance yet, submit your favorite family-friendly joke in the comments below, and use #Day2 so we can find it!  We'll be selecting the next group of winners from both last video's submissions and this video's submissions after 1pm on Friday June 22!

Huge thanks to Zuru for providing the Tangles for our winners!

title: How to (Explain) ADHD
description:
What IS ADHD, anyway? And how do you EXPLAIN it to people? We teamed up with the ADHD tribe to bring you simple explanations of the most common ADHD challenges, with metaphors submitted by the community and animated by Edward! Enjoy!

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd
My TEDx talk on ADHD: http://bit.ly/2sKXHGl
What it’s really like to have ADHD: https://youtu.be/ji0hg1LduU8

Business email: business@howtoadhd.com 
(I'm businessing!)

Links! 

Through Your Child’s Eyes: https://u.org/2Jwj2tz

Dr. Hallowell’s website: http://www.drhallowell.com/
Racer Brain, Bicycle Brakes (video): http://bit.ly/2Jpjfme
Read his memoir! https://amzn.to/2Md4Oj4

Hyperfocus: http://bit.ly/2l3LHv7

Act Your (Executive) Age! http://bit.ly/2sV3599

Presentations of ADHD: http://bit.ly/2sKx1FL
Child vs. Adult ADHD: http://bit.ly/2sKhtBI
ADHD treatment: http://bit.ly/2HDI7AO
Why Stimulants Help ADHD (video): http://bit.ly/2HxPwlj
Emotional Dysregulation (video): http://bit.ly/2sVDvAL
ADHD FAQ: http://bit.ly/2JsNRz8

Working memory in adults: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23688211
Brain development in ADHD: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conb.2014.11.007
Emotional dysregulation in children with ADHD: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27299358
Neuroanatomic and Cognitive Abnormalities in ADHD: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4293331/
Hyperfocus in Adult ADHD: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27681531
Safety and Effectiveness of ADHD medications: https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14740338.2017.1389894?journalCode=ieds20
Nonpharmacalogic treatments: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29848556
Mindfulness and Executive Function: http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0963721413495869?journalCode=cdpa

Barkley, B. A. (2015) Emotion Dysregulation is a Core Component of ADHD. In R. A. Barkley (Eds.), Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder: A handbook for diagnosis and treatment (4th ed.). New York, NY, US: Guilford Press.

localizations.de.title: Wie (erklären) Sie ADHS
localizations.de.description:
Was ist ADHS überhaupt? Und wie erklärt man es anderen? Wir haben uns mit unserem ADHD-Tribe zusammengetan, um euch einfache Erklärungen zu den häufigsten ADHS-Herausforderungen zu geben, mit Metaphern, die von der Community eingereicht und von Edward animiert wurden! Viel Spaß dabei!

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Unterstützen Sie uns auf Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd
Mein TEDx Vortrag über ADHS: http://bit.ly/2sKXHGl
Wie es wirklich ist, ADHS zu haben: https://youtu.be/ji0hg1LduU8

Geschäftliche E-Mail: business@howtoadhd.com 
Ich bin jetzt professionell!

title: QUESTION TIME! Best Fidgets, Sensitivity, Budgeting, and Choosing a Career!
description:
SO MANY QUESTIONS – tried to answer as many as I could, until I saw Edward's hand getting tired.

(Use a tripod?  What?  That's insufficiently impulsive!)

What do you guys think?  Should we do more of these?

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd
Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd
Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd


Timecodes of Questions and Answers!

00:42 Nick W How do I become a more punctual person? 

2:06 CricketStar: What are the best fidgets that don't distract others?
         The Tangle: http://tangle.zuru.com/

2:38 Alena Keene: What was your biggest struggle with ADHD as a kid?

3:46 Vincisomething: Advice for burnouts and sensory overload?

4:46 Morgan: Can inattentive brains still be hyper?

5:00 Sandvich Tsar: Can you be diagnosed with ADHD and something else?

5:19 Melanie Diaz: What do you tell someone when they say ADHD is just an excuse?

6:25 Unnati Kapoor: How do you choose the right career path?
    (Link to Lydia X.Z. Brown: https://www.autistichoya.com/ )
    (Link to Brené Brown: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iCvmsMzlF7o )

8:52 LOLUnicorn: Is ADHD to blame for me being sensitive and emotional?
    (Link to Emotional Dysregulation video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2kew2JhKq3Y )
    (Link to some of Dr. William Dodson's writing on emotional dysregulation: https://www.additudemag.com/slideshows/adhd-emotions-how-they-affect-your-life/ )

9:14 Michelle Maloney: How do you deal with finances when you are a married couple?

10:06 Cecelia Morrisson: How long before you see improvement with medications?

10:52 Superbrain: Why are you so BUSY?!

12:56 Cool Kid Awesome: How can I stop procrastinating?

14:47 Lalah Battle: When is merch coming back?

15:11 Eldritch Dwarf: Can we have an entire video for question time every month?


"The Show Must Be Go”
Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com)

https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/

description:
Whether you're working with your own ADHD brain or someone else's, the goal is the same: to get the best out of that brain. Here's how you can do that! 

****

title: 3 Apps That Can Help You Spend *Less* Time on Your Phone
description:
I love my phone as much as the next ADHD brain, but sometimes when my life feels crazybusy I remember putting my phone down can help. Suddenly I have time to do things! Like clean my kitchen! Play with my puppy! READ! And other times I just NEED to put it down so I can focus. Here are some apps that can help!


****

Links to 3 Apps That Can Help You Spend *Less* Time on Your Phone: 

Forest:http://bit.ly/2HQ9Ikf
Space: http://bit.ly/2Hkt9EQ
Focus Screen-Free Driving: http://bit.ly/2HdFNFk

There are lots more like these, feel free to add your favorites in the comments below!
